DOC.HEAD: Panel Praises Fed's Independence
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Banking Committee has defended the independence of the Federal Reserve Board and praised the central bank's inflation-fighting program. ``A suitable degree of independence for the Federal Reserve is essential,'' the committee said Wednesday in a report to Vice President Dan Quayle, adding, ``the Fed's current structure appropriately provides some insulation from (political) pressures.'' Reviewing the Fed's attempt to curtail inflation by slowing economic growth just short of a recession, the committee said, ``This policy has been reasonably successful.'' It also said the Fed's plan to depress growth slightly next year in order to achieve modest reductions in inflation ``does not appear unreasonable.'' The report comes after several attack's on the Fed's independence from Bush administration officials and members of the House. President Bush and members of his Cabinet have criticized the central bank for what they call its excessive concern with inflation and dampening growth too much. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp has said the administration and Congress should have more influence over the Fed. He is backed by the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., who introduced legislation earlier this year which would force the Fed to operate more openly and consult more closely with the administration. Earlier this month, House Banking Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said he would launch a major review of the Fed next year. The Senate panel's report was signed by its chairman, Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. Only one of the panel's 20 members dissented, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., who is chairman of the Budget Committee. Sasser, in a written addition to the report, said the Fed, which has eased its tight money policy since June, has been ``not nearly aggressive enough'' in allowing interest rates to decline. ``I think that there is increasing evidence that we may be sliding into a recession. If this is so, it will be the result of the Fed's tightening,'' he said.
